newsitem.title: SPAIN: Basque police brace for violence in ETA strike. [CORRECTED 16:50 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Basque police brace for violence in ETA strike. [CORRECTED 16:50 GMT]

text.p: Spanish security forces are bracing for violence during a strike and demonstrations in the major Basque cities on Friday, organised by the political arm of the ETA separatist (corrects from "terrorist") group.
The last such protests, on February 15, deteriorated into a violent clash between thousands of demonstrators and police who at one point fired live bullets into a crowd, wounding two people.
Spain's Basque police ordered a tripling of street forces on Thursday to counter threats against schools and businesses by the group, Herri Batasuna (HB).
Education officials in the northern region denounced letters sent by HB to headmasters, teachers and students, warning them to stay away from classes during Friday's strike.
"As a preventitive measure, the Ertzainza (Basque police) will triple its ordinary numbers," Basque regional government Deputy Interior Minister Jose Martiarena told reporters.
Police aim to keep roads clear, guarantee functioning of public transport, prevent picketing and keep strike organisers from filling shop keyholes with silicone to stop businesses opening.

HB called the strike to protest at the imprisonment of most of its leadership in recent weeks. Eighteen of the 25-member HB leadership have been jailed for failing to answer a Supreme Court summons to appear on charges of distributing an illegal pro-ETA video during Spain's 1996 election campaign.
The Basque government has outlawed the strike, saying it is politically motiviated.

The prospect of trouble has exacerbated tensions in the region, already running high since ETA (Basque Homeland and Freedom) stepped up its attacks this year, killing six people including a Supreme Court judge.
Basque businessmen complained earlier in the week that HB had sent threatening letters warning them to heed the strike call or pay the consequences.
"This strike can only succeed by means of fear because the majority is against it," Basque Interior Ministry spokesman Juan Ramon Ruiz said on Thursday.
An estimated 10 to 15 percent of Basques support HB.
